I20060803-0835

I got the SOE below after pressing Ctrl+Space in a Java Editor. The proposals list quickly showed up, but then I got the workbench "Internal error" dialog.

This happens reproducably in my workspace with the code below; but I could NOT reproduce in an empty workspace.

package xy;
public class Try {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        System.out.println(IFace.CONST); // content assist after I of IFace
    }
}
interface IFace {
    int CONST= 1 << 3;
}

WORKSFORME with SWT from head and Eclipse 3.2.  Getting a nightly ...

I20060803-1200

WORKSFORME

0) Created a new workspace 'workspace-junk'
1) Checked out
    org.eclipse.swt,
    org.eclipse.swt.win32.win32.x86,
    org.eclipse.swt.tests
2) Created new Java project 'Junk'
3) Created new Java package 'xy'
4) Pasted in the code fragment, followed instructions
5) Hit Ctrl+Space
6) Got a dialog that said the operating took too long to complete
7) Tried it again and this time, it worked

What gives?  Anyone else seeing this?

As I said, I could also not reproduce in a fresh workspace, but I didn't want to waste time hunting for preferences in case you could see the problem from the stacktrace.

However, here are complete steps with I20060804-0010 & JDK 1.5.0_07:
1) New workspace
2) Copy code from comment 0 and paste into empty Package Explorer (creates a new project, package, and compilation unit)
3) Preferences > Java > Appearance > Type Filters:
   - Click New, add "sun.*"
   - Click New, add "javax.swing.*"
4) Move workbench window to the very top of the screen
5) Hit Ctrl+Space after "I"
6) Make proposal popup as high as possible, at least such that "IDDataTypeValidator" becomes visible
7) press Esc
8) press Ctrl+Space again
=> Boom!
FH can you try to reproduce this?  I could not with the steps in comment 3, but I'm on win2000.  (My VM was also different, but this is not a likely cause).

I can reproduce this problem on my machine on eclipse 3.2 and Eclipse 3.3 M1 (I20060807-2000).
Windows xp sp2, windows xp theme.
I can no longer reproduce this problem with HEAD.
I can still reproduce with I20060822-1200 as well as with HEAD by following the steps in comment 3.

I got a similar stack overflow with latest 3.2.1 maintenance build, using the update manager dialog. I tried to resize the dialog, and got the stack overflow.
It only occurred when grabbing dialog bottom right corner and dragging it to upper left corner.

In update manager, I did reach the point where I had selected an update site, then had gone to next pane for choosing individual updates from the selected site(s).
This pane is entitled "Search Results".
(sorry I cannot disclose here the exact site I was using)
Considering this for 3.2.1
Fixed for 3.2.1

The summary is that Windows draws right away when setting a column width rather than damaging an area and waiting for a repaint.  Here is the comment from the work around:

/*
* Feature in Windows.  When LVM_SETCOLUMNWIDTH is sent,
* Windows draws right away instead of queuing a WM_PAINT.
* This can cause recursive calls when called from paint
* or from messages that are retrieving the item data,
* such as WM_NOTIFY, causing a stack overflow.  The fix
* is to turn off redraw and queue a repaint, collapsing
* the recursive calls.
*/

NOTE: I only fixed the recursive crash.  I didn't fix every set width for every column.  Do you have some example code that shows the problem you are seeing?  If so, please enter a bug report for it.  Thanks.

Still see the problem quite often with the following stack trace: (No, this has nothing to do with table column resize problem which I have fixed according to your suggestion. Thanks.)

1) Did you hit a tab key?
2) How deep is the widget hierarchy?  You might simply be running out of stack.
No, I did not hit a tab key. For the 2nd question, apparently there is an infinite loop and this problem seems only happening on XP.

I see "org/eclipse/swt/widgets/Display.translateTraversal(Bytecode PC:162)" on the stack.  What key did you press?

How many levels is the parent child hierarchy of widgets?  Windows has a bizarre limitation which escapes me right now and will fail in strange ways when this limit is reached.
Anything more?
Verified that original problem (comment 3) is solved in 3.2.1 and I20061017-0800.
